p: Although S. rostratum is highly abundant in China, it is usually found in open, disturbed habitats, such as roadsides, fallow fields and field margins [ 6]. In the US, this weed was reported as an agricultural pest in Oklahoma [ 8], Nebraska and Wyoming [ 9]. Field experiments conducted in cotton ( Gossypium hirsutum L.) fields in Oklahoma showed that crop plant heights were decreased at greater densities of S. rostratum [ 8]. In the same study, yield reduction was also observed, with a damage of 480 kg ha âˆ’1 at a weed density of 64 plants/10 m row. In Israel, S. rostratum was first documented at the Jezreel Valley in 1953 [ 4]. Since then, several field populations were located in the Jordan Valley, the Golan Heights, the Hulla Valley and at the Mediterranean Sea coastline ( Figure 1). S. rostratum may appear in several germination flashes, starting from spring and continuing throughout the summer; thus, both young and mature plants may coexist at the same field. Different sensitivity levels between young and mature S. rostratum plants can reduce the effectiveness of chemical weed control.
